text: hey this is Leslie Samuel here from

this question was from Brittany and she
was asking me to explain the concept of
resistance when it comes to blood flow
and that's a great question it's a very
important concept to understand when it
comes to the circulatory system when I
think about resistance the first thing I
like to think about is a hose like okay
so here we have a garden hose and you
probably know how this functions you
hook it up to a faucet or something of
the what do you call it is it a faucet
anyhow you hook it up to something that
allows for water to flow and it goes
through this hose and it comes out on
the other end in some cases you have
this nozzle that you can kind of press
but in other cases it's just the hose
the goal is to get that water from where
it's starting to the end so that you can
water your plants or water wash your car
or something of that sort
the key thing is you have fluid that's
flowing through this hose to get to a
specific location now there are gonna be
a number of things that are gonna
influence how the water travels through
this hose if this hose is very very
narrow the space that the lumen or the
opening if it's a very narrow opening
there's gonna be more resistance because
as the water is just you know flowing
through the hose the water is gonna be
bumping up against the sides bumping it
up against other water molecules and all
that kind of stuff and it there's gonna
be some of that resistance just because
of the fact that you have something
flowing through a tube and it's gonna
encounter friction all right now so if
it's narrower it's going to have more
resistance it's not gonna be as easy for
you to get as much through if it's wider
of course there's gonna be less
resistance if you have a huge hose if
the diameter of this hose is something
like this in comparison to this you're
gonna have much more water
that can flow through it there's gonna
be significantly less resistance now
let's look at it a different way oops
sorry about that let's go back to that

let's say this is the lumen or the
opening of the holes this is the

resistance right yeah it's gonna be
harder to get the same amount of fluid
through because it's clogged this is the
same type of concept that I want you to
understand when it comes to the way that
blood is flowing through the body so you
have the heart that's beating if of
course it's sending blood to the lungs
it's sending but the blood to the arms
and to the legs and to the kidneys and
all of the structures in the body that
need blood but these are just like these
garden hoses these are tubes and as the
blood is flowing through the tubes it's
gonna be hidden against the wall it's
gonna be hitting against other red blood
cells and white blood cells and all that
stuff it's going to be encountering
resistance now just like there were
factors that's gonna influence this the
flow of water through this hose they're
also gonna be factors that are gonna
influence the flow of water through
these blood vessels
if the blood vessels get narrower
there's gonna be more resistance if it's
wider there's gonna be less resistance
and this is something that the body uses
the body compensates so that if you're
trying to get a lot of blood to a
particular area but not to others
you're gonna take advantage of the
processes of vasoconstriction Faisel
constriction and basil dilation
vasoconstriction and vasodilation
so in vasoconstriction you're
constricting the blood vessels to make
them narrower because you have smooth
muscle that's surrounding those that can
constrict and cause the
the lumen to be narrower or you can
dilate you can have the muscles relaxed
so that okay so this might be
vasoconstriction and this is
vasodilation and you can kind of channel
it to make it go to the places that you
want it to go and this is something that
the body does regularly to get blood to
where it needs to go and not as much to
where it doesn't need as much when
you're much more active there's gonna be
vasodilation going to the the blood
vessels that are going to the muscles
those need to dilate and the blood
vessels that are going to your stomach
for example those are gonna constrict so
you're not getting as much blood flowing
there so here we're gonna have a higher
resistance and I'm actually going to
call it peripheral resistance peripheral
resistance and here you're gonna have a
lower peripheral resistance all right so
we're modulating this we're trying to
take advantage of the fact that I mean
if all your blood vessels were to just
vasodilate then the blood would just
kind of pull to the lower extremities
you don't want that you want to take
advantage of vasoconstriction and
vasodilation but the main concept of
resistance has to do with the fact that
as the blood is flowing through the
vessels it is gonna be encountering
friction it is gonna be encountering
